newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish zloty rise sparked by foreign bond buying.
newsitem.headline: Polish zloty rise sparked by foreign bond buying.

text.p: The Polish zloty firmed against the basket of currencies in live trade on the back of a strong speculative currency-selling trend sparked by an early foreign purchase of Polish two-year bonds, dealers said.
They estimated the total foreign interest in Polish fixed income bonds over the last four days at around $60 million.
"There has been growing interest in fixed Polish T-bonds on the secondary market since last Thursday ... foreigners bought roughly $60 million of the paper," said Pawel Dudzinski from PKO SA.
The zloty closed at 2.29/2.26 percent from the trading band centre, stronger than yesterday's close at 2.16/2.09 percent.
It was at 2.8038/50 to the dollar, down from 2.7970/90 on Tuesday and at 1.8620/25 to the mark, up from 1.8690/00.
Dealers were mixed about a short-term outlook for the zloty with some saying it would now drop anchor between 2.2 to 2.3 percent from the parity rate.
"The zloty is likely to trade at 2.2 to 2.3 percent from parity tomorrow," said Tomasz Nowakowski from Bank Handlowy SA.
But others said it might fall back to 1.9 or 2.0 percent from parity after hitting 2.35 percent in midday today.
"The 2.3 percent from parity level seems unusual for the zloty. It may go back to 1.9 to 2.0 percent in the near future," said Konrad Kolasinski from Amerbank in Warsaw.
The central bank fixed the zloty at 2.8050 against dollar and at 1.8625 per mark, lower than the average session's rates, which could signal the zloty's weakening on Thursday.
Yields on the secondary T-bill market remained flat with the benchmark quoted 19.52/47 percent in a sign the firmer zloty did not spark any foreign profit-taking on T-bills.
"The situation on the spot forex market did not influence the T-bill market, foreigners were absent," said Krzysztof Kozuchowski from ING Bank in Warsaw.
Some foreign players said, however, any further investment in Polish paper was unlikely because of the zlotys' relative strength.
"The current zloty exchange rate is strong which may put people off from buying Polish paper," a dealer at London bank said.
